_header: Grant gracious God grant me this time
Note:
For a later version, post 1544, cf. Flodden Field, ff. 120-125; London, British Library Addit. 27879, p. 117; pr. Weber (1808)
XWeber, Henry William. The Battle of Flodden Field. Edinburgh: Ballantyne, 1808; Evans (1810)
XEvans, Thomas. Old Ballads: historical and narrative, with some of modern date. London: for R. H. Evans by W. Bulmer, 1810; Hales and Furnivall (1867)
XJohn Wesley Hales, and Frederick James Furnivall. Bishop Percy’s Folio Manuscript: Ballads and Romances. 3 vols. London: Trübner, 1867-68, 1.318-40.
Subjects: historical poems; Stanley, family history; history, family
_description: The House of Stanley: Scottish Feilde — 422 alliterative lines

BodDepc130.First Lines:
that dred was sone afterRayled full of redd
                    roses…
BodDepc130.Last Lines:
…That have hearkened me hereThat heded well my
                    tale
BodDepc130.Note:
Facsimile of a very long and narrow piece of parchment which contains
                    only this poem. Begins imperfectly. At the end:
                    ‘Finis’.

BLAdd27879.Editions:
Hales,  John Wesley,  and  Frederick James Furnivall, eds.  
             Bishop Percy’s Folio Manuscript: Ballads and Romances.
         3 vols. London: Trübner, 1867-68: 1.212-34.
Child,  Francis James. 
             The English and Scottish Popular Ballads.
         5 vols. in 10 parts. Boston and New York: Houghton, Mifflin,
            1882-98: 6.355.
Oakden,  J. P.,
                        ed.  
             “Scottish ffeilde.” 
             Chetham Miscellanies, new series
             vol. 6. 
             Chetham Society
         n.s. 94 (1935), item e. 
Gray,  Douglas. 
             The Oxford Book of Late Medieval Verse and Prose.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1985: 9-10.

RylandsLyme.First Lines:
…that dred was some afterPayles full of redd rosesand
                    riches enoughthere he bekered with a bore…
RylandsLyme.Last Lines:
…that haue hearckened me hereand heard well my tale
                    Finis
RylandsLyme.Note:
Long strips of parchment, probably originally a roll, now folded; begins
                    imperfectly with gaps where missing or destroyed by animals; transcription is
                        Oxford,  Bodleian Library Dep. c.130 [facsimile of Lyme Hall]. Followed by ‘The names of the lordes and
                    gentilmen of Scotland that were slaine in deede attis late battaill vpon
                    brankston more.’
RylandsLyme.Editions:
Robson,  John,
                        ed.  
             “The Scottish Field.” 
             Chetham Miscellanies.
            Vol. 2.
             Chetham Society
         o.s. 37 (1856).
